ESKAPE is an acronym that encompasses the scientific names of six highly virulent and antibiotic-resistant bacterial pathogens, including: Enterococcus faecium, Staphylococcus aureus, Klebsiella pneumoniae, Acinetobacter baumannii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Enterobacter spp. This group of Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria can evade or 'escape' common antibiotics due to their increasing multi-drug resistance (MDR). As a result, they are the leading cause of life-threatening nosocomial or hospital-acquired infections in immunocompromised and critically ill patients worldwide, who are most at risk. The food chain is one of the main drivers of MDR transmission, as food is not sterile and can usually have microbiological contamination or become contaminated at certain stages of the food chain (i.e. cross-contamination, recontamination). Indeed, the food chain can act as a driver for MDR spread, enabling the survival or even multiplication of MDR pathogens. MDR transmission is not exclusive to foods of animal origin or fish; plant foods can also harbour MDR microorganisms, as vegetables can be contaminated during primary production by water contaminated with faecal material from wastewater from surrounding farms. In general, pathogens are not common in food and the main risk arises from the high prevalence of non-pathogenic microorganisms that can transfer AMR genes to other microbial species, including foodborne pathogens. It is well documented that genes encoding resistance are transferable between different bacteria in farm animals and also from them to bacteria in food and humans by horizontal gene transfer (i.e. transformation, conjugation and transduction).

As the environmental impact of the growing tide of plastic in the oceans and on land becomes more apparent, scientists are scrambling to create alternatives to petroleum-based plastics. But it has proven tricky to make bioplastics that are cheap, strong, water-resistant and break down quickly when their use is over. The race for renewable plastics has led to bioplastics made from corn starch, sugar cane, potatoes, coffee grounds, food waste, algae and wood waste powder.

Arsenic (As) occurrence in rice is a serious human health threat. Worldwide, regulations typically limit only carcinogenic inorganic As, but not possibly carcinogenic dimethylated oxyarsenate (DMA). However, there is emerging evidence that “DMA”, determined by routine acid-based extraction and analysis, hides a substantial share of dimethylated thioarsenates that have similar or higher cytotoxicities than arsenite. Risk assessments characterizing the in vivo toxicity of rice-derived dimethylated thioarsenates are urgently needed. In the meantime, either more sophisticated methods based on enzymatic extraction and separation of dimethylated oxy- and thioarsenates have to become mandatory or total As should be regulated.Since the publication of the 2009 EFSA opinion on arsenic in food new studies have become available on the toxic effects of organic arsenic. Furthermore it has become clear that dimethylmonothioarsenate (DMMTA) is formed from methyl arsenate due to the application of sulphate fertilisers, and that this substance could be more toxic than methylarsenate. It is therefore appropriate to update the hazard identification and characterisation of organic arsenic. On the basis of the available occurrence data for organic arsenic or literature information on organic arsenic in food, the exposure could be estimated in order to carry out an assessment for the risks for human health related to organic arsenic in food. In view of different properties of the methylated arsenic species, arsenobetaine, arsenolipids and arsenosugars, it is appropriate to assess the organic arsenic species in 2 separate opinions: an opinion on methylated arsenic species and an opinion on arsenobetaine, arsenolipids and the arsenosugars, which should also include any other possible organic arsenic species. After finalising the risk assessments on inorganic and organic arsenic, also the combined exposure to inorganic and organic arsenic should be assessed (source: Open EFSA (europa.eu))

Exposure of coho salmon (Oncorhynchus kisutch) in the Pacific Northwest of the United States to stormwater causes unexplained acute annual mortality when adult salmon migrate to urban streams to reproduce. Investigating this phenomenon, researchers identified a highly toxic quinone transformation product of N-(1,3-dimethylbutyl)-N′-phenyl-p-phenylenediamine (6PPD), a ubiquitous antioxidant found in tyre rubber worldwide. Retrospective analyses of representative U.S. West Coast road runoff and stormwater-influenced streams revealed the widespread occurrence of 6PPD quinone (<0.3 to 19 micrograms per liter) at toxic concentrations (median lethal concentration of 0.8 ± 0.16 micrograms per liter). These results reveal unexpected risks of 6PPD antioxidants to this aquatic species and imply toxicological relevance for residues derived from tyre rubber.

Staphylococci (and their enterotoxins) are the leading cause of food-borne illness (CFTI) with a confirmed or suspected agent in France and are a major cause of food-borne illness worldwide. Staphylococcal CFTIs are due to the ingestion of heat-resistant staphylococcal enterotoxins (SE), preformed in food at the time of preparation. The vast majority of these CFTIs occur in restaurants, school canteens or in the home. Staphylococci and ES are most often detected in food samples and more rarely in the vomit and stools of patients. Very often, only ES are detected in contaminated food; the bacterial strains producing these toxins have been eliminated by the preparation conditions. It is therefore sometimes difficult to link ES to the producing strains. The detection of ES in food is therefore a crucial step in the surveillance of staphylococcal CAI.

The European Commission asked EFSA for a scientific opinion on the risks for human health of the presence of grayanotoxins (GTXs) in ‘certain honey’ from Ericaceae plants. The risk assessment included all structurally related grayananes occurring with GTXs in ‘certain’ honey. Oral exposure is associated with acute intoxication in humans. Acute symptoms affect the muscles, nervous and cardiovascular systems. These may lead to complete atrioventricular block, convulsions, mental confusion, agitation, syncope and respiratory depression. For acute effects, the CONTAM Panel derived a reference point (RP) of 15.3 μg/kg body weight for the sum of GTX I and III based on a BMDL10 for reduced heart rate in rats. A similar relative potency was considered for GTX I. Without chronic toxicity studies, an RP for long-term effects could not be derived. There is evidence for genotoxicity in mice exposed to GTX III or honey containing GTX I and III, showing increased levels of chromosomal damage. The mechanism of genotoxicity is unknown. Without representative occurrence data for the sum of GTX I and III and consumption data from Ericaceae honey, acute dietary exposure was estimated based on selected concentrations for GTX I and III reflecting concentrations measured in ‘certain’ honeys. Applying a margin of exposure (MOE) approach, the estimated MOEs raised health concerns for acute toxicity. The Panel calculated the highest concentrations for GTX I and III below which no acute effects would be expected following ‘certain honey’ consumption. The Panel is 75% or more certain that the calculated highest concentration of 0.05 mg for the sum of GTX I and III per kg honey is protective for all age groups regarding acute intoxications. This value does not consider other grayananes in ‘certain honey’ and does not cover the identified genotoxicity.

Blastocystis hominis is probably the most common protozoan detected in human  faecal samples worldwide. Infection occurs in both immunocompetent and immunocompromised individuals. Reported prevalence ranges from 2% to 50%, with  the highest rates reported for developing countries with poor environmental hygiene.  Infection appears to be more common in adults than in children. However, one study  showed that peak infection occurs at 10 years of age and then later in life. Pathogenicity  of B. hominis is controversial because of the nonspecific symptoms and prevalence of  asymptomatic infections. Some case–control studies of individuals with and without  symptoms show no difference in the prevalence of B. hominis. Symptoms attributed to B. hominis include watery or loose stools, diarrhoea, abdominal pain, anal itching,  weight loss and excess gas. Duration of infection is not well known; some infections  can last for weeks, months or years. In some patients, the symptoms resolve, even  though Blastocystis can still be detected in stools. It has been suggested that B. hominis may be a commensal organism that becomes pathogenic when the host is immunosuppressed, is malnourished or has other infections.Contaminated water sources can lead to outbreaks of parasitic infections like Blastocystis sp., significantly straining healthcare systems and impacting community health. A systematic review analyzed 24 studies with 2,451 water samples from 15 countries, finding an overall prevalence of 18.8% for Blastocystis sp., with the highest infection rate in wastewater (35.5%) and notable levels in tap water (19.1%).

Bacillus cytotoxicus is a member of the Bacillus cereus group. This group comprises closely related organisms of varying pathogenicity including the food-borne pathogen Bacillus cereus sensu stricto. Some members of the B. cereus group can cause two distinct forms of food-borne illness: Firstly, the diarrheal syndrome that is linked to three enterotoxins - Hbl, Nhe and CytK - and secondly, the emetic syndrome caused by cereulide toxin preformed in food. B. cytotoxicus was isolated for the first time in the context of a severe outbreak of diarrheal disease leading to fatalities and was described as a species in 2013. The organism harbors a specific variant of the gene encoding the enterotoxin cytotoxin K designated cytK-1. It has been reported that the cytotoxin K variant CytK-1 confers substantially higher toxicity than CytK-2. B. cytotoxicus is thermotolerant and might be missed using routine diagnostic screening for B. cereus group organisms at 30°C. Targeted screening at temperatures of at least 37°C has shown that dried food matrices containing potato starch very commonly harbor B. cytotoxicus.For instance, a recent study found a prevalence of 95% in mashed potato powder sold at retail level in Switzerland. Recent reports from the UK suggest that B. cytotoxicus also occurs in association with insect-based foods, which have recently gained popularity. In cytotoxicity assays, the few B. cytotoxicus strains that have been characterized to date range from non-toxic to extremely toxic, with toxicity surpassing the toxicity of a B. cereus outbreak strain (NVH 0075-95) used as a reference. Information on B. cytotoxicus is still limited and it is unclear if the organism’s capacity to germinate, produce enterotoxins, and exhibit cytotoxic effects in the intestine is comparable to that of B. cereus.B. cytotoxicus is a Gram-positive, aerobic organism able to produce spores. The species description was based on five strains, four of which were linked to foodborne disease (Guinebretière et al., 2013). B. cytotoxicus is thermotolerant and able to grow at temperatures of up to 53°C. Further characteristic features are the absence of starch hydrolysis and the dependency from tryptophan for growth. B. cytotoxicus also characteristically harbors the cytK-1 variant of the cytotoxin K gene.

titel: Potential hazards associated with new species of freshwater molluscs
kurzinfo: New species, whether invasive or newly imported, are appearing in Switzerland. This goes hand in hand with the emergence of new trendy recipes or harvests. As these shellfish are not well known, they could harbour new pathogens and become a new threat to the population. For instance, in a study conducted in China, C. perfringens from aquatic source showed a high isolation rate, notably in cooked clams. C. perfringens toxin type G in clams was detected for the first time and the toxin genes cpb, cpe, and netB were detected for the first time in cooked clams.  The average antibiotic resistance rates of the strains to tetracycline, clindamycin, and ampicillin were 45 %, 20 %, and 16 % respectively.

titel: Streptococcus suis - from pigs to humans
kurzinfo: The Gram-positive bacterium Streptococcus suis is an emerging zoonotic agent that causes fatal infections such as septicaemia and meningitis in humans. In recent decades, the number of reported human cases of S. suis infection has increased rapidly, and three epidemics were recorded in China in 1998, 2005 and most recently in 2016. The recent increase in the global spread of virulent S. suis suggests its adaptive evolution in humans. However, this has remained largely elusive as no evidence of genetic adaptation to humans has been reported. The bacterium Streptococcus suis has long been known to cause swine disease. A genomic analysis has narrowed down where and when the deadly bacterium jumped from pigs to humans: in Europe in the 1960s or 1970s. To trace the evolution of S. suis, researchers from China analysed 1,634 S. suis genomes collected over 36 years from pigs and humans in 14 countries. The genomes fell into three distinct groups, one of which was found mainly in humans. This group included strains that caused severe diseases in zebrafish, which the authors used as a model for human diseases. Some of these strains had been collected from pigs that showed no signs of disease, suggesting that asymptomatic animals may have acted as vectors that transmitted the bacterium to humans. The researchers traced the origins of the human group to Europe during the 1960s and 1970s, when the continent was exporting pigs worldwide.

Aeromonas spp., such as A. hydrophila, are bacteria that can form cell-damaging toxins. They are widespread in nature and are found mainly in surface waters (lakes, rivers), hence the term 'water germs'. The bacteria have been detected in fish, but also in insects and domestic and farm animals, and can cause gastroenteritis and diarrhea in humans. A. hydrophila is already known to be a pathogen in fish and seafood; the germ can also be detected in the meat of livestock, in vegetables and dairy products.

titel: Human milk donation and associated health risks
kurzinfo: In the absence of a lactarium in French-speaking Switzerland, young mothers give, sell, buy, or receive breast milk. There are platforms for these exchanges on social networks, but they do not seem to be supervised by health professionals. The journalist in this article raises the microbiological and toxicological risks that the failure to respect certain basic sanitary rules (use of medication and bacterial contamination by Salmonella, Streptococcus, Staphylococcus) may represent for breast milk and therefore for the newborn. In 2022, a first lactarium will be opened, it is possible that these platforms will or will not cease to exist, but the question concerning the professional supervision of this issue remains if they continue to exist.

titel: Detrimental impact of cellulose derivatives food additive on the gut microbiota
kurzinfo: Additive derivated from cellulose - such as microcrystalline cellulose (E 460), powdered cellulose (E 460), methyl cellulose (E 461), ethyl cellulose (E 462), hydroxypropyl cellulose (E 463), hydroxypropyl methyl cellulose (E 464), ethyl methyl cellulose (E 465), sodium carboxy methyl cellulose (E 466) and enzymatically hydrolysed carboxy methyl cellulose (E 469) - are often used in the food industry because of thier thechnological properties. However, since several years, these additives are controversial because of their potential adverse health effects. The EFSA stated in 2018 that they would be no safety concern at the reported uses and use levels for the unmodified and modified celluloses. However, results of a randomized Controlled-Feeding Study of Dietary Emulsifier Carboxymethylcellulose (CMC) published in 2021 support the notion that the broad use of CMC in processed foods may be contributing to increased prevalence of an array of chronic inflammatory diseases by altering the gut microbiome and metabolome. Because these additives are commonly used in meat-alternatives and regular consumer of these product would be more exposed to these additives, increasing the risk of developing inflammatory diseases.

titel: Chaga mushroom (Inonotus obliquus) as natural food supplement
kurzinfo:
Inonotus obliquus, is a fungus which is growing on trunks of birch and alder trees. In english it is called "chaga". It is a popular health product, with claimed therapeutic action. It is claimed to be rich in vitamins and minerals. In Estonia chaga products (pieces, powder, extracts in alcohol or water) are on the market, with more than 60 products and more than 20 producers. There is a search for export markets. Inonotus obliquus is marketed as a healthy lifestyle product, superfood and universal medicine suitable for everyone. Estonia did some analysis and concluded based on these results: 

If chaga is consumed in recommended quantities, the contents of aluminium and heavy metals (As, Cd, Ni, Pb, Sn) don’t pose health risk for adults
The oxalate contents (up to 80% of ADI) may induce the risk of kidney stones or nephropathy in adults
Due to the smaller body weigt of children: 

Possible health risks due to Ni and Pb
The exposure to Al and Cd contribute a major part of TWI
The exposure to oxalates may reach up to 352% of ADI


The concentrations of minerals are generally small (below 10% of NRV)
Concentrations of vitamins were below detection limits

titel: Listeria monocytogenes serotyp 4b ST6 in cheese
kurzinfo: An outbreak of human listeriosis in Switzerland was attributed to persistent environmental contamination of a cheese factory with Listeria monocytogenes serotype 4b, sequence type 6, cluster type 7488. Whole genome sequencing was used to match clinical isolates with a cheese sample and with samples from numerous sites within the production environment.

Sapoviruses cause acute gastroenteritis in humans and animals. They belong to the genus Sapoviruses within the family Caliciviridae. They infect people of all ages, both in sporadic cases and outbreaks. The clinical symptoms of sapovirus gastroenteritis are indistinguishable from those caused by noroviruses, so laboratory diagnosis is essential to identify the causative agent. Sapovirus infections are a public health concern, causing acute gastroenteritis in people of all ages worldwide in both outbreaks and sporadic cases. Outbreaks often occur in semi-enclosed environments. Outbreaks due to food-borne transmission of sapoviruses have also been reported. Sapoviruses are genetically and antigenically diverse. Currently, reverse transcription PCR (RT-PCR) assays are widely used for the detection of sapoviruses from clinical samples because of their high sensitivity and broad reactivity and the lack of sensitive assays for antigen detection or cell culture systems for the detection of infectious viruses. Sapoviruses were first discovered in 1976 by electron microscopy in diarrhoeal samples from humans. To date, sapoviruses have also been detected in various animals: pigs, mink, dogs, sea lions and bats (Oka et al. 2015). Sapovirus is thought to be spread from person to person, through sewage infiltration into drinking water sources and via contaminated food. Among food-borne transmissions, seafood is a recognised source of sapovirus infection.

titel: Impact of rising gas prices on CO2 availability and electricity used in food industry
kurzinfo:
There is likely to be a shortage of CO2 throughout Europe over the next months, which is likely to have an impact on the food and beverage industry. This appears to be arising due to reductions in fertiliser manufacture (due to gas price increases) of which carbon dioxide is a by-product. This fact sheet will highlight the food safety issues which may arise as food business operators try to manage their CO2 and electricity supply. CO2 is a gas that is used extensively in the food and beverage industry for a variety of food purposes, such as adding bubbles to beer and soft drinks, drinks dispensing systems, livestock stunning gas and extension of shelf-life of foods with modified atmosphere packaging (MAP). The potential impact of the sharp increase in electricity prices and possible supply shutdowns on food safety are also discussed.

Potential issues emerging from a reduction in CO2 availability: I. Shelf life , II.Animal welfare, III.Product ranges , IV.Risks from Alternative Gases
Potential issues to emerge from the increased price of electricity: I.Cold stores, II.FBOs businessess,  III. Cleaning, IV. Cooling, V. Drying

Trifluoroacetate (TFA) is a mobile and persistent substance that is primarily introduced into the water cycle through the degradation of various fluorochemicals and remains there for an unforeseeable period of time. There is already a high baseline load of TFA in many water bodies with some regional hotspots. This background paper presents current data and estimates on sources, input pathways, loads, impacts and measures on TFA. It gives an outlook on first activities and options to comprehensively minimise TFA inputs to the environment. Despite gaps in knowledge, it becomes clear that consistent regulation and an overarching minimisation strategy must be initiated in the short term.

The Nipah virus (NiV) can cause an often severe infection in humans and pigs. In rarer cases, infections in dogs, cats, ruminants or horses have also been detected. Guinea pigs and hamsters are also experimentally infectable. Reservoir hosts are fruit-eating fruit bats of the genus Pteropus, from which it can be passed on to other animals and humans. Infected animals and patients excrete the virus with respiratory secretions, saliva and urine. Contact with respiratory secretions is considered the main route of transmission in nosocomial infection. In the first NiV outbreak in 1998/99 in Malaysia and Singapore, transmission from fruit bats occurred via excreta or infected fruit ingested by pigs. Transmission from infected pigs to humans (285 infections with 105 deaths) occurred through direct contact with infected animals and their secretions (saliva, urine, blood). The virus can also be transmitted between humans.an approved vaccine or therapy to protect potentially exposed or infected humans or animals is not yet available.

TBE or tick-borne encephalitis (encephalitis = inflammation of the brain) is an infectious disease caused by the TBE virus. The virus is transmitted by the bite of an infected tick (Castor bean tick). This is the most significant way of transmitting the virus. An alimentary transmission by unpasteurised milk, or milk products from acutely infected goats or cattle was reported on and has been discussed repeatedly in the past. In Germany, two outbreaks, caused by alimentary transmissions, were detected in 2016 and 2017 respectively. TBE is a viral infection caused by one in three tick-borne encephalitis virus (TBEV) subtypes belonging to the Flaviviridae family: Central European, Siberian and Far Eastern (formerly known as Russian spring-summer encephalitis).

Enterococci are widespread and can be found in soils, surface water, vegetation and in fresh and processed foods, especially those of animal origin. Some antibiotic-resistant E. faecium and E. faecalis strains are responsible for an increasing rate of nosocomial infections.Three studies report the identification of a novel botulinum neurotoxin gene cluster (BoNT gene cluster) in the genome of an E. faecium strain. These findings are worrying as E. faecium are widely distributed in terrestrial animals as well as being a core component of human gut flora. There are concerns that botulism neurotoxins could be produced by such Enterococci. In food, BoNTs are produced preferably under low-oxygen conditions by Clostridium botulinum, and food poisoning is usually associated with food that has been inadequately sterilised. This often involves homemade canned vegetables.

Researchers in Slovenia have published the results of a long-term, national Clostridioides difficile food surveillance project (formerly Clostridium difficile). Positive results were detected in meat, vegetables and fruits, as well as poultry. For meat, the most direct route of Clostridioides difficile contamination is via faeces during slaughter, but post-production processing could also play a role. The main sources of contamination of vegetables are soil or indirect faecal contamination through irrigation or fertilisation. Hand contamination during handling of meat and vegetables is also possible. The study found that the proportion of Clostridioides difficile-positive meat and vegetable samples is increasing every year. However, the number of samples tested was too small to speculate on possible trends, and given the low detected prevalence of contaminated samples, the food safety risks are likely to be very low for the types of food tested.

Cyclospora infection is an intestinal disease caused by a unicellular parasite. Humans can be infected by the fecal-oral route; most commonly via contaminated water or food treated with it (such as salads, berries, herbs, etc.). In 2017 and 2018, several outbreaks occurred in the United Kingdom and the United States. In each of these outbreaks, numerous people fell ill. As a result, various food products were withdrawn from the market. International companies have also been affected. The list of outbreaks is long and seems to have been increasing in recent years.

Vegan nutrition is in vogue. Companies are responding by creating new milk substitutes, including cashew nut-based ones. In Switzerland, cheese has been made from cashew nuts since 2015. 50 to 60 tonnes of organic cashews are imported from Vietnam every year. The cashew milk is processed raw and not pasteurised, only the "ricotta" and the products sold in the retail trade are thermised at 65 degrees to make them last longer. The concern here is that products are not necessarily pasteurised, especially as nuts can be contaminated by micro-organisms and/or pesticides. In many countries, nuts are harvested by hand and dried in the sun. Contamination can occur through insects, birds, rodents, but also through air and soil. Wet, humid conditions also pose a significant risk for the formation of aflatoxins. Nuts and seeds are known sources of salmonella, but E. coli O157 can also be frequently detected.

An online vegan food company says it has discovered the ingredient in one of its products that has been making consumers severely ill. Symptoms included severe gastrointestinal distress and highly elevated level of liver enzymes. Several consumers needed to have their gallbladders removed as a result. The company announced that it had identified the culprit in the French lentil & leek crumbles: Tara flour, made from the seeds of tara trees.

titel: Possible new focus of Diphyllobothriasis, Central Europe
kurzinfo: Diphyllobothriasis is a human parasitic infection that is widespread in the Northern Hemisphere. Popular sport fish such as pike and perch are the source of human infection. The number of cases decreased drastically after World War II. Today, only small foci remain, mainly in the Alpine lakes of northern Italy, Switzerland, and France, where diphyllobothriasis continues to circulate. The source of infection is the consumption of popular sport fish, such as pike and perch. A study documents the autochthonous origin of diphyllobothriasis in a popular tourist destination in Central Europe, which likely marks recent colonization of the parasite.

Meat allergy was first observed in the 1990s and formally described in 2009, which makes it a relatively recent arrival to the compendium of allergic conditions. Its most curious quality may be that it is seemingly triggered by a tick bite. In America, the culprit, called the lone-star tick, females have a distinctive white splotch on their backs, is common in the warm and humid Southeast, where most cases of meat allergy have been diagnosed.This syndrome is called AlphaGal syndrome (AGS). Individuals are allergic to a sugar molecule, which does not occur in humans but is on a large number of cells in all other mammals. It is a sugar with the name galactose-alpha-1,3 galaktose, or alpha-galactose, or alpha-gal for short. AGS patients develop a disease after eating mammalian meat, dairy products or even cosmetics containing animal ingredients. Allergy symptoms: from thick lips, shortness of breath and itchy skin to circulatory problems and unconsciousness. Many suffer from abdominal pain, nausea and diarrhoea.

titel: Shiga toxin-producing E. coli in flour
kurzinfo: STEC from different types of flour have caused epidemics in CAN (O121) and the USA (O121, O26). Several  product recalls were issued in the USA. Based on the publication by Mäde et al. (2017), investigations were also carried out at the FSVO which confirmed the findings (detection of STEC in types of flour).

titel: Encapsulation Systems for Antimicrobial Food Packaging Components
kurzinfo: Antimicrobial active packaging has emerged as an effective technology to reduce microbialgrowth in food products increasing both their shelf-life and microbial safety for the consumer while maintaining their quality and sensorial properties. In the last years, a great effort has been made to develop more efficient, long-lasting and eco-friendly antimicrobial materials by improvingthe performance of the incorporated antimicrobial substances. With this purpose, more effective antimicrobial compounds of natural origin such as bacteriocins, bacteriophages and essential oils have been preferred over synthetic ones and new encapsulation strategies such as emulsions, core-shell nanofibres, cyclodextrins and liposomes among others, have been applied in order to protect these antimicrobials from degradation or volatilization while trying to enable a more controlled release and sustained antimicrobial action. This trend brought new challenges regarding the incorporation of these new products into these novel packaging materials in terms of antimicrobial-packaging material compatibilities and, the most important one, the decreased stability of these natural-based compounds as they are more prone to suffer degradation by heat and light. Furthermore, there are other losses to be faced when incorporating some of these antimicrobials in packaging materials due to their inherent volatilization.

titel: Antibiotics to treat citrus greening disease
kurzinfo: Citrus greening disease, also known as Huanglongbing (HLB), is a bacterial disease affecting citrus fruit and is spread through an invasive insect, the Asian citrus psyllid (Diaphorina citri). Once a tree is infected, there is no effective way of controlling or curing it. The disease poses no threat to humans or animals but can infest all types of citrus trees making it a serious threat to the global citrus fruit industry. Antibiotics are being used in some countries to handle the problem. In the USA, there is a discussion about allowing farmers to use two antibiotics (streptomycin and oxytetracycline)  several times a year as a routine treatment. There is little scientific evidence on the long-term use of these drugs in crop environments. Further, the use of antibiotics on a small-scale has previously shown to slow down the spread of the disease. This allows farmers to harvest a few more crops from infected trees, however, the spread cannot be prevented. The potential use of antibiotics on a larger scale increases concerns about the developing resistance to antibiotics.

titel: Soybean oil - cause of neurological diseases
kurzinfo: The consumption of soybean oil has increased dramatically over the last fifty years and is associated with obesity and diabetes. To test the hypothesis that soybean oil diets alter hypothalamic gene expression in relation to metabolic phenotype, the research group below performed RNA sequencing analysis with male mice that were fed isocaloric, high-fat diets based on conventional soybean oil (high in linoleic acid, LA), a genetically modified low-LA soybean oil (plenish) and coconut oil (high in saturated fat, without LA). Both soybean oil diets had similar but not identical effects on the hypothalamic transcriptome, while the coconut oil diet had a negligible effect compared to a low-fat control diet. Dysregulated genes were associated with inflammation, neuroendocrine, neurochemical and insulin signalling. Oxt was the only gene with metabolic, inflammatory, and neurological relevance that was upregulated by both soybean oil diets compared to both control diets. Oxytocin immunoreactivity in the supraoptic and paraventricular nuclei of the hypothalamus was reduced, while plasma oxytocin and hypothalamic Oxt were increased. These central and peripheral effects of the soybean oil diet correlated with glucose intolerance but not with body weight. In the coconut oil diet enriched with stigmasterol, a phytosterol derived from soybean oil, changes in hypothalamic Oxt and plasma oxytocin were not observed. The research team discovered about 100 other genes that are also affected by the soybean oil diet. They believe that this discovery could have implications not only for the energy metabolism, but also for important brain functions and diseases such as autism and Parkinson's disease. However, it has been indicated that there is no evidence that the oil causes these diseases. Furthermore, the team noted that the findings only applied to soybean oil - not to other soy products or other vegetable oils.

titel: Poor diet increases cancer risk - scientists uncover missing link
kurzinfo: A research team has unearthed new findings which may help explain the connection between cancer risk and poor diet, as well as common diseases like diabetes, which arise from poor diet. The insights gained from this study hold promise for advancing cancer prevention strategies aimed at promoting healthy aging. Poor diet can increase the risk of obesity, heart disease, type 2 diabetes, and some cancers. However, experts have not yet found any firm causative links between individual dietary components and cancer. A new study has discovered that methylglyoxal — which is produced when glucose is broken down in cells — may help explain the link between poor diet and cancer. They suggest that a long-term poor diet leads to an increase in the production of methylglyoxal, which switches off cancer-preventing genes, increasing cancer risk.

The category of performance-enhancing food supplements has undergone a significant change in the last ten years. For a long time, the market was dominated by products that were intended to increase athletic performance (e.g. through building muscle).In recent years, however, another market segment has established itself, that of so-called nootropics (substances with an effect on the central nervous system). These nutraceuticals (traditional/herbal remedies, food supplements, functional food) focus on increasing cognitive performance. Thus, physical and, above all, mental performance is to be increased by these products.

Helicobacter pullorum belongs to the genus Helicobacter and it is a fastidious, microaerophilic, non-sporulated, and Gram-negative spirally curved motile bacillus with monopolar flagellae. It is bileresistant and requires a microaerobic environment supplemented with H2 in which growth occurs at 37 and 42 ◦C.  It belongs to the enterohepatic Helicobacter species (EHH) that colonize the host intestine and hepatobiliary system . H. pullorum naturally infects many poultry birds, some rodent species, and also humans. , it has been isolated from the feces of human patients with enteritis as well as healthy humans. H. pullorum is associated with several clinically significant infections in humans , such as colitis and hepatitis, inflammatory bowel disease, recurrent diarrhea, and bacteremia . H. pullorum is also thought to play an important role in the development of Crohn’s disease.  Helicobacter pullorum is an emerging foodborne pathogen that commonly colonizes the gastrointestinal tract of poultry, causing gastroenteritis.  The bacterium may be transmitted to humans through undercooked poultry meat.

titel: Arcobacter spp. in foods and water
kurzinfo: Arcobacter butzleri, recently renamed Aliarcobacter butzleri comb. nov., are aerotolerant Campylobacter-like organisms previously classified as Campylobacter. The genus Arcobacter was described in 1992. A. butzleri is found in environmental samples and untreated water appears to be a potential source of infection. In industrialised countries, the most important source of human contamination is food. Indeed, A. butzleri has been isolated in several farmed animals and is found in a variety of retail meats, including chicken, beef, pork, and lamb, with a high prevalence in poultry. Milk and dairy products may also be affected. A. butzleri colonises diverse and numerous ecological niches, such as water sources, ready-to-eat foods like vegetables, and food products of animal origin like meat, milk and cheese, fish and seafood. In addition, its survival and growth has been demonstrated in raw, pasteurised and UHT milk, and in the production and storage of ricotta cheese and artisanal water buffalo mozzarella cheese. These findings have led to A. butzleri being considered one of the emerging pathogens in milk and dairy products/environments of the 21st century (Fusco et al., 2020). Some Arcobacter species can cause gastrointestinal diseases in humans and animals. These are usually associated with abdominal pain and nausea, and watery diarrhoea but can also be asymptomatic. In general, a mild course of disease is observed in humans.

Melatonin (N-acetyl-5-methoxytryptamine) is known as a potential free radical. In a study by Li et al. (2021), the prolonged effect of the shelf life of white champignons was investigated. These had a significantly longer shelf life depending on the treatment. Melatonin also delays the leaf senescence of Chinese cabbage (Tan et al. 2020) or the yellowing of broccoli (Wu et al. 2021 or Miao et al. 2020). It is also employed in the ripening of fruit (such as tomatoes; Sun et al. 2020) or to increase the resistance of grapes (Gao et al. 2020). Melatonin is found in plant-based foods and in very small doses also in animal foods. The highest melatonin content is found in cranberries (up to 9,600 µg/100g dry weight). Other sources of melatonin are some types of mushrooms (saffron milk cap, common boletus, agaricus bisporus, chanterelle), some types of cereals (corn, rice, wheat, oat, barley), mustard seeds, dried tomatoes and peppers, and some types of wine (wikipedia).

titel: Residues of veterinary drugs in groundwater
kurzinfo: Due to the intensification of food production in Europe, veterinary medicines have become a critical component in animal husbandry. The administration of these products can potentially lead to their presence in environmental waters such as groundwater, which is why they are now considered potential groundwater contaminants. In Ireland, several residues of anthelmintic and anticoccidial veterinary drugs have been detected in groundwater. 22% of 106 sampling sites detected residues of anthelmintics in the range of 1-41 ng/L and anticoccidials in the range of 1-390 ng/L. Residues were higher near intensive farming sites. These veterinary drug compounds are associated with a range of acute as well as chronic side effects, and their degradation products may have additional adverse effects.

Infections with Aspergillus spp. show a high morbidity and mortality rate in risk groups. Over 30 different species are responsible for this, but the species Aspergillus fumigatus (A. fumigatus) is the most common. Azoles, mainly triazoles, are used to prevent or treat Aspergillus spp. infections in humans and plants. Resistance of Aspergillus usually results from long-term treatments with triazoles. However, A. fumigatus has been isolated from patients who have never been treated with such drugs. It is therefore suspected that resistant strains spread in the environment. These strains may have acquired their resistance through the use of triazole-based fungicides. Azole resistance is therefore described as an emerging problem. In Germany, an increased number of aspergilloses have been observed in the last 5 years. In agriculture, resistance to Aspergillus also seems to be increasing, probably due to changes in cultivation techniques (minimum tillage) which may promote contamination and the growth of Aspergillus. Another risk is the emergence of cross-resistance. Studies have shown that resistant Aspergillus spp. are also resistant to medicinal azoles, emerging from fungicides.

Listeria innocua is commonly described as a non-pathogenic Listeria species. However, recent studies now show that various genetic elements are present that confer the characteristics of a pathogenic strain to L. innocua. In vitro and in vivo assays have shown that atypical haemolytic L. innocua is virulent, can actively cross the intestinal epithelium and can spread systemically to the liver and spleen, albeit to a lesser extent than the reference strain L. monocytogenes EGDe .

The ALS virus, first discovered in China in 2017, is a member of the flavivirus family along with the TBE virus. After being bitten by ticks, several patients suffered from fever and headaches – the typical symptoms of a TBE infection. And yet, no antibodies against the TBE virus or its genetic material could be detected in the affected individuals. Instead, the researchers found a previously unknown RNA virus, the Alongshan virus. The complete gene sequence of ALS viruses was found in numerous tick samples collected in several regions of Switzerland in 2021 and 2022. “Surprisingly, ALS viruses were detected in the tick samples far more frequently than TBE viruses,” says Cornel Fraefel, director of the Institute of Virology. Since the symptoms of an infection with ALS viruses are similar to those of an infection with TBE viruses, the Alongshan virus could already pose a public health concern in Switzerland, albeit hitherto unrecognized. At present a possible transmission also via milk, like TBE, is not known.

Organosilicone surfactants (OSS) adjuvants are silicone-based copolymers with super –penetrating, -spreading and –wetting properties to potentiate the active ingredient against plant and animal pests and diseases. Over 700’000 tons of OSS are produced globally per year out of over 4.5 million tons of total of organosilicon production making this class of formulants the most widely used amongst all high-production chemicals for pollution worldwide. The metabolism and fate of OSS are almost unstudied on published literature. Toxic effects from OSS are observed in honeybees. Several recently published peer-reviewed journals on this topic highlight the safety concerns of organosilicone surfactant on humans and animals.

As inflation rises and consumer purchasing power falls, food manufacturers and retailers are trying to adapt to avoid eroding their margins.Cheapflation (or the lowering of food quality) consists of replacing certain products or foods with cheaper substitutes (food or not). The aim is obviously to maintain margins or sell more products. Examples abound on the internet and the Reddit site in particular echoes them. The most obvious example of cheapflation is that of certain ice creams now called 'frozen desserts', because the dairy products that made them up have been replaced by fillers.

titel: Ostreopsis - a new algae at European coasts
kurzinfo:
In the summer of 2021, a new and unexpected phenomenon on the beaches of the Basque Country occured: a clinical picture reminiscent of an influenza-like syndrome, affecting entire families but also beach professionals (lifeguards, beach restaurant waiters, etc.). Water samples taken showed a high concentration of a microalga not visible to the naked eye called Ostreopsis. No serious cases were observed out of the 674 cases reported to the authorities in Bordeaux. Climate change and human activities are causing changes in the marine environment. It is in this context that new intoxications are appearing. These microalgae, invisible to the naked eye, grow on macroalgae and on the sea bed.They can also contaminate fish and shellfish through bioaccumulation.The particularity of Ostreopsis spp. is that it emits toxins in seawater and in particular at the level of the blooms. They are then aerosolised in the sea spray. One can therefore be intoxicated by the respiratory route without having set a foot into the water, through the skin when swimming, but also by ingestion when consuming contaminated products.

These microalgae produce toxins similar to palytoxin, responsible for :
Neurological signs: tingling, burning and headaches
ENT (ear, nose and throat) infections and respiratory signs: runny nose, coughing, breathing difficulties,
Skin signs resembling urticaria,
Cardiac signs: tachycardia, high blood pressure,
Digestive signs: nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea,
General signs: fever, muscle and joint pain.

Brevetoxins (Ptychodiscus toxins, PbTx) are neurotoxic algal toxins of the dinoflagellate species Karenia. The toxins are named after Karenia brevis. Karenia brevis is a marine alga and component of the phytoplankton of tropical regions and is regularly observed in the Caribbean and especially in the Gulf of Mexico. Here it occurs as one of the causative agents of "red tides", known as red algal blooms, which are formed by mass reproduction of these algae (Wikipedia). Other microalgae are also suspected of producing brevetoxins. This is the case with K. mikimotoi, K. bicuneiformis, Chattonella marina, C. antiqua, Heterosigma akashiwo and Fibrocapsa japonica. Brevetoxins are neurotoxins that cause irritation of the mucous membranes and respiratory tract. The effect is similar to that of ciguatoxin, but those are less toxic. Brevetoxins were first detected in France in November 2018 in mussels in Corsica (117 μg/kg digestive gland). The associated water samples for phytoplankton monitoring showed the presence of Karenia spp. (a genus of microalgae, some species of which produce brevetoxins).

Yersinia pseudotuberculosis is an enteric pathogen causing mild enteritis that can lead to mesenteric adenitis and septicemia in elderly patients. Most cases are sporadic, but outbreaks have already been described in different countries. Savin et al.(2022) report for the first time a Y. pseudotuberculosis clonal outbreak in France, that occurred in 2020. An epidemiological investigation pointed towards the consumption of tomatoes as the likely source of contamination.

E. multilocularis is ranked 7th in terms of public health consequences for France by Anses (French Agency for Food, Environment, Health and Safety at Work). The assessment is based on an incidence score of 1 (low) combined with a disease severity of 4 (very high): Between 2013 and 2015, 29 cases occurred in France, with a noticeable increase in cases in the regions along the Swiss border (Grand Est; Bourgogne-Franche-Comté and Auvergene-Rhône-Alpes). Positive findings in foxes are also found in the areas mentioned.In Germany, a national database for alveolar echinococcosis is being established. Further information and assessment of the risk can be found in the dissertation by Schmidberger J. (2017). The main endemic area in Germany is in Baden-Würtemberg and Bavaria.The prevalence estimate for Germany in the period from 1992 to 2016 was 0.64 cases per 100,000 inhabitants, for Baden-Württemberg the estimated prevalence in the same period was 2.18 cases per 100,000 inhabitants and in Bavaria 1.48 cases per 100,000 inhabitants were observed in this period.

titel: Is it safe to cook with essential oils?
kurzinfo: Essential oils, which are extracted from plants, are best known for their use in aromatherapy, a complementary health practice that involves inhaling the scents or mixing the oils with lotion or massage oil. There has been a growing interest in other uses for these oils, however, including using them for cooking. In addition to irritating and burning the tissues of the mouth and esophagus, consuming essential oils directly can cause seizures, hallucinations, and coma. A study published in 2019 in The Medical Journal of Australia reported that toxicity from ingesting essential oils is on the rise, and “increasing frequency and severity of essential oil poisonings have been reported in Europe and the United States. Some essential oils have been linked to adverse effects when ingested, even in tiny amounts. These are particularly: Eucalyptus Oil, Sage Oil, Wintergreen Oil.

When foods containing sucralose are heated above 120°C, harmful substances such as organochlorines (e.g., polychlorinated dibenzodioxins, dibenzofurans, chloropropanols) can be formed through dechlorination and decomposition. The sweetener sucralose (E955) was internationally deemed as safe within the framework of the authorisation of additives and will be re-evaluated by the EFSA by the end of 2020 at the latest. The current state of knowledge (see BfR 2019) on the stability of sucralose and the decomposition products formed during heating should be taken into account. There are still many data gaps on the identity and concentration concerning these substances and the exposure estimation, and the BfR ( German Federal Institute for Risk Assessment) was not able to make a conclusive risk assessment in its statement (2019). The question arises whether measures should be taken in the meantime.

titel: Pheophorbides and other hazards in algae products
kurzinfo: Algae products with high levels of phophorbide (chlorophyll metabolite) have in the past (1970s) in Asia led to considerable health damage due to phototoxic effects in the consumers concerned. As a result, official limits were set for certain product groups in parts of Asia, but not so in the EU. It is therefore the responsibility of the food business operator to limit the content of pheophorbides in foods on the European market to a technologically unavoidable level in order to meet the requirements of European food law. The Japanese limit is 100 mg of pheophorbide present per 100 g, or 160 mg of cumulative pheophorbide (i.e. the amount of pheophorbide present plus the amount formed by chlorophyllase activity within a three-hour incubation at 37°C) per 100 g. In Taiwan, the limits only apply to dried seaweed with less than 7% residual moisture. They also do not apply to red and brown algae. According to the available literature, the minimum amount of pheophorbide that is photosensitising is 25 mg/day. Other chemical hazards - associated with algae - concern in particular iodine, cadmium, arsenic and lead, as well as microbiological hazards (see further documentation). Recent studies also show that red algae can be used in animal feed to reduce methane emissions from cattle stomachs. Chemical hazards from algae could find their way into the food chain via feed.

A company called GABA labs is working on alcohol replacements. The Sentia botanical drink is made with food grade herbs that contain molecules that work on the GABA system, which produces a state of relaxation and sociality. By targeting the GABA system, the drink avoids targeting other neurotransmitter systems that alcohol affects, which can lead to problems when larger doses are consumed. The use of these herbs is believed to minimize the risk of dependence, as they are not known to activate the dopamine system, which is a key driver of alcohol dependence and craving. Alcarelle, a synthetic molecule targets subtypes of the GABA system to mimic the effects of alcohol in a more specific way. The goal is to license Alcarelle as an ingredient that can be used extensively as an alternative to alcohol by any drink company in the world. The molecule is designed to offer the pleasure of alcohol with less harm and a lot fewer calories.

Tert-butylhydroquinone (also known as TBHQ, E319) is an organic compound belonging to the polyhydric phenol family and is a derivative of hydroquinone containing a terc-butyl group. TBHQ is a preservative found in many foods, including edible oils, frozen meats (especially fish) and processed foods such as crisps and biscuits. TBHQ do not always have to be listed in the ingredients list. It has been used in food for many decades, it has no other function than to increase the shelf life of the product, as an antioxidant it prevents the oxidation of fats. In 2021, a study by the US Environmental Working Group (EWG), analysing data from Toxicity Forecaster (ToxCast), showed that the preservative TBHQ is harmful to the immune system, based on both animal studies and in vitro toxicology studies. This finding is particularly worrying in the time of the coronavirus pandemic. The EWG recommends that immunotoxicity testing of chemicals in food and food contact materials should be prioritised to protect public health from their potential adverse effects on the immune system.

titel: Coxiella burnetii increase in animal population
kurzinfo: Q fever is an acute disease caused by the bacterium Coxiella burnetii. The natural reservoir of the pathogen is cattle, sheep, goats, dogs, cats, some wild animals and ticks. Infected animals often show no symptoms, but excrete the pathogen mainly via birth products of farm animals (e.g. placenta), which are usually highly infectious, but also via faeces, urine or milk. In the majority of cases, infection in humans occurs through inhalation of dust containing the pathogen, but also through direct contact with infected animals. People who are in close contact with animals (animal owners, veterinarians, slaughterhouse employees, etc.) are particularly affected. Depending on the wind conditions, however, people in the immediate vicinity of infected animals can also become infected. In about half of the people infected, the infection causes no symptoms or only mild flu-like symptoms that disappear spontaneously. The other half experience sudden fever, chills, sweating, fatigue and headache, which can be complicated by inflammation of the lungs, liver, heart muscle or brain. Q fever is usually treated with antibiotics to prevent the disease from becoming chronic. Besides sporadic cases, outbreaks can also occur.There is a steady increase of reported cases in the animal population since 2014 in Switzerland; cattle: 2014: 54; 2021: 131; Goat: 2014:3; 2021: 19; sheep 1; 2021:10). In 2020, a total of 51 human cases of Q fever were reported to the FOPH, which corresponds to a reporting rate of 0.6 new cases per 100,000 inhabitants. In the previous year, there were almost twice as many cases due to an outbreak, with 101 cases. The outbreak was most likely linked to two infected goat herds in Ticino. There is no similalr increase in the human population as observed in the animal population.

Staphylococcus argenteus has recently been proposed as a new species within the S. aureus complex (SAC). S. argenteus has been found in many countries and can pose a threat to human health. It is known to cause various diseases in humans such as skin and soft tissue infections, sepsis and staphylococcal food poisoning. A study by Wakabayashi et al. (2022) investigated the prevalence of S. argenteus in retail fresh food and poultry slaughterhouses in Japan. Of 642 food samples examined, S. argenteus was successfully isolated in 21 of 151 (13.9 %) chicken samples. No isolations were confirmed from pork, beef, fish or vegetable samples in retail markets.The findings of Wakabayashi et al. (2022) suggested that chicken meat was significantly contaminated with this bacterium and could be a source of human disease. The molecular epidemiological study by Wakabayashi et al. (2022) found that meat processing plants could be partly responsible for the spread of the bacterium from the environment to food and vice versa.Staphylococcus argenteus has been recently established as a novel species of the Staphylococcus aureus complex. It is known to cause various human diseases, such as skin and soft-tissue infections, sepsis, and staphylococcal food poisoning, although the source of infection has not been clearly described. In food poisoning cases, the source of bacterial contamination in food is unknown.

Staphylococcus argenteus was isolated from chicken meat and slaughterhouse samples.


Twenty-one isolates from chicken meat were classified into 14 genotypes.
Sequence type 2250, a clone spreading globally, was not a predominant genotype.
WGS showed possible bacterial contamination of chicken meat in the slaughterhouse.

Food safety issues caused by cryogenic microorganisms during storage in domestic in domestic refrigerators have attracted widespread attention. Diversity of foods, such as raw and cooked meats, seafood, rice and flour products, vegetables and fruit, etc. as well as the abundance of nutrients, have become the best habitat for the growth and reproduction of cryogenic micro-organisms in the refrigerator. In addition, the colonisation of cryogenic microorganisms on the inside wall of the refrigerator is difficult to remove and eliminate, which will further affect the quality and further compromise the quality and safety of food stored in the refrigerator and may cause outbreaks of foodborne illness. In this review, the the storage location of different foods in the refrigerator, the types of organisms that commonly organisms that commonly contaminate foods in the refrigerator, and are comprehensively described. A survey conducted in Switzerland showed that approximatively  25% of respondents who wanted to reduce their energy costs raised the fridge temperature. The population doing this was found to be mainly the older generation and therefore part of the vulnerable population. This study is consistent with the results of another study conducted in the Netherlands. A survey among 1,020 Dutch consumers assessed their knowledge and behavior regarding refrigerators. The mean temperature of 534 domestic refrigerators on the bottom shelf was 5.7 °C. Outcomes of the survey were used to estimate the number of listeriosis cases per year due to consumption of RTE-cooked meat products among different population risk groups. The study showed that the more extreme high storage conditions were found in refrigerators of the elderly, and this indicates that there is a need for more targeted communication about good storage practices. Due to demographic changes, rising temperatures and the constant increase in energy prices, we might expect more and more outbreaks. Therefore, risk communication tailored to vulnerable groups could help to reduce the risks.

The prevalence of Providencia spp. in foods is still largely unknown . Although pathogenicity has not yet been clearly demonstrated, there is much to suggest that P. alcalifaciens, for example, can cause diarrhoea. Both developing and industrialised countries can be affected by outbreaks caused by Providencia spp.. Insufficient personal hygiene, inadequate food storage conditions and cross-contamination during preparation are often cited as causes of foodborne infections. In view of global trade flows and rising temperatures due to climate change, food on the European market could also be increasingly contaminated with Providencia spp. and cause outbreaks.

β-N-methylamino-L-alanine (BMAA) is a non-protreinogenic amino acid and is produced by various free-living or symbiotic cyanobacteria (blue-green algae). It can also be produced by eukaryotic phytoplankton such as Diatoma and dinoflagellates. BMAA is a neurotoxin and has been linked in the literature to neurodegenerative diseases such as ALS (amytrophic lateral sclerosis) and Alzheimer's disease, but the connection is not yet clear. The neurotoxin is ingested through the consumption of contaminated water, crustaceans, shellfish, fish and algae-based food supplements. The greatest concentrations of BMAA are present during the bloom periods, but accumulations can also occur in the tissues of seafood and fish, which means that BMAA can be ingested throughout the year.

Tenuazonic acid (TEA) is a mould toxin (mycotoxin) produced mainly by moulds of the genus Alternaria; more than 70 toxins have been described for this genus. Due to the widespread occurrence of Alternaria spp. on plants used for food production, TEA can often be detected in various foods. Contamination of tomatoes and tomato products (e.g. ketchup) with TEA is a known problem and occurs mainly when already mouldy tomatoes are processed. Accordingly, the detection of TEA can serve as a quality characteristic, as increased toxin contents are an indication that ingredients affected by mould have been processed. In addition to tomatoes and tomato products, cereals and cereal products, sunflower seeds and spices are also among the foods that may be preferentially contaminated with alternariatoxins. Due to a lack of comprehensive toxicological data, there are currently no legal regulations for the assessment of alternariatoxins in food and thus no maximum values for food. However, a scientific opinion of the EFSA from 2011 is available, which is used as a guideline for the risk of alternariatoxins in food. According to this, the TTC (threshold of toxicological concern) for TEA is 1.5 µg/kg body weight per day. Accordingly, a person weighing 60 kg may consume a product containing up to 90 µg/kg TEA every day without suffering health damage.

titel: Extraintestinal E. coli from poultry flocks
kurzinfo: Escherichia coli is one of the most important bacterial species studied, commonly found as a commensal intestinal inhabitant of humans and various animals. However, E. coli also represents an extremely versatile and diverse pathogen capable of causing infections of the gastrointestinal tract, termed intestinal pathogenic E. coli, while others, termed extraintestinal pathogenic E. coli (ExPEC), cause infections outside the gastrointestinal tract. ExPEC include the following different pathotypes based on the host and site of infection; uropathogenic E. coli (UPEC), which are responsible for urinary tract infections (UTI); avian pathogenic E. coli (APEC) causing the most common disease, colibacillosis in poultry; septicaemia-associated E. coli (SEPEC) and neonatal meningitis-causing E. coli (NMEC) responsible for septicaemia and neonatal meningitis, respectively. ExPEC infections in humans are a significant cause of morbidity or mortality and are also mainly responsible for economic losses in poultry due to reduced production. Poultry could act as a source of extraintestinal infections such as urinary tract infections, meningitis, septicaemia in humans or systemic disease in animals and pose a significant threat to food safety and human and animal health.

titel: Foodborne illnesses caused by Edwardsiella tarda
kurzinfo: Edwardsiella (E.) tarda is a bacterial pathogen with a wide host range in fish, reptiles, amphibians and mammals. As a fish pathogen, E. tarda has a high economic impact. Foodborne diseases caused by the consumption of contaminated fish and seafood have been described in the past, particularly in Asian countries. There are first indications that the number of human cases of E. tarda infection is increasing and that cases are also occurring outside Asia. Climate change, environmental pollution and an increase in aquaculture are being discussed as possible triggers for the increase and spread. This BeoWarn report summarises current knowledge about the pathogen E. tarda as a possible cause of foodborne diseases.

Ruminococcus gnavus was first identified in 1974 as a strict anaerobe in the gut of healthy individuals, and for several decades, its study has been limited to specific enzymes or bacteriocins. With the advent of metagenomics, R. gnavus has been associated both positively and negatively with an increasing number of intestinal and extraintestinal diseases from inflammatory bowel diseases to neurological disorders. This prompted renewed interest in understanding the adaptation mechanisms of R. gnavus to the gut, and the molecular mediators affecting its association with health and disease. From ca. 250 publications citing R. gnavus since 1990, 94% were published in the last 10 years.

titel: Coconut oil as a cuisine trend
kurzinfo: Given the high prevalence of diet-related health problems in modern society, including obesity and related problems such as type 2 diabetes, there is also a growing movement towards healthier eating. One of these trends is the increasing use of coconut oil, which is often touted as having potential health benefits. While most oils in our normal diets contain mainly long-chain fatty acids (LCFAs), coconut oil, along with some other products such as palm kernel oil, contains mainly medium-chain fatty acids (MCFAs), usually 12 carbon atoms in length. MCFAs in general, whether from natural sources or synthetic, have become increasingly important in nutrition. While in controlled studies the results have been mixed [1], there is some evidence that MCFAs have some health benefits, including a decrease in obesity due to their faster metabolism in the body [2]. There is also evidence to suggest some health risks, such as the consumption of coconut oil leading to significantly higher LDL cholesterol levels compared to other oils [3] and the ability to induce insulin resistance [4]. In general, however, the exact mechanisms of MCFA metabolism have been poorly understood, making a thorough risk assessment difficult. A recent study [5] has examined the metabolism for MCFAs in detail compared to LCFAs and found that mainly two enzymes are involved, DGAT1 and DGAT2. The results shed some light and may not only explain why Etomoxir, a substance developed about 40 years ago to inhibit beta-oxidation of fatty acids, has massive side effects in patients, but also show that ingestion of coconut oil or other MCFAs may contribute to chronic diarrhoea in patients with a mutation in DGAT1. The link between DGAT1 deficiency and chronic diarrhoea had already been shown in a previous study, but was not sufficiently understood [6].

Coumarin is a natural flavouring and fragrance substance found in many plants (e.g., lavender) and thus also in some foods. It is found in higher concentrations in certain types of cinnamon and in woodruff. From a toxicological point of view, coumarin is considered to be a cause for concern as it has been shown to be carcinogenic in animal experiments in high doses; an increased cancer risk for humans has not yet been proven. Furthermore, coumarins inhibit the vitamin K metabolism and thus influence blood clotting. In high intake quantities, coumarin can cause liver damage, in extreme cases hepatitis with liver failure. Even small amounts of the substance can cause liver damage in sensitive individuals, although this damage is reversible.The genotoxicity (genetic damage) of coumarin could not be confirmed. Coumarin may be contained in cinnamon capsules in particular. At higher doses, it is possible to exceed the daily dose for coumarin (Verbraucherzentrale, Deutschland).

An artificial sweetener called neotame can cause significant harm to the gut.  It does this harm in two ways. One, by breaking down the layer of cells that line the intestine. And, two, by causing previously healthy gut bacteria to become diseased, resulting in them invading the gut wall. Neotame was developed as an alternative to aspartame with the aim of being a more stable and sweet version of the traditional sweetener. It is very stable at high temperatures, which means it is a good additive to use in baked goods. It is also used in soft drinks and chewing gum. Neotame has been approved for use in more than 35 countries, including the UK, although the European Food Safety Agency is currently reviewing the sweetener as part of a series of evidence‐based risk assessments of certain sweeteners. While neotame has been shown to change the profile of gut bacteria, very little research has investigated the effect of neotame at the cellular level.

Various initiatives have been launched to reduce food waste. One of them is 'too good to go'. Too good to go, for example, is a movement against food waste and the app of the same name is the world's largest business-to-consumer marketplace for leftover food. In Switzerland, more and more unsold food is sold this way. The idea of using technology to connect people in the fight against food waste was developed in Denmark in 2016 and quickly implemented across Europe. The Too Good To Go app connects people at the right time and place to reduce food waste. Currently, 'to good to go' is active in 14 European countries, and has also been present in Switzerland since summer 2018. The Too Good To Go app aims to create a win-win-win situation: Users receive food that has expired or is close to its expiry date at a reduced price. In addition, there are campaigns that supplement the best-before date (BBD) with the phrase 'often good for longer'. Numerous manufacturers in Switzerland have already added this supplement to the best-before date on their products (Press room, to good to go).Food waste is an economic problem, but also a moral one. But what about food safety? In recent times, food is being used beyond its expiry date, but how safe is it? Since November 2019, a retail chain in Switzerland has also been offering 'wonder bags' to counteract food waste. Bags filled with surplus products that can no longer be sold can be ordered and collected. The products cannot be selected by the buyer. (Source: LT Magazine, Issue 11, 2019. 6.11.2019).

Straws are one of the disposable plastic articles that will be subject to a Europe-wide sales ban from 3 July 2021. This was stipulated in EU Directive 2019/904 of 5 June 2019, which raises the question of whether and how frequently used everyday products, the majority of which have been made of plastic up to now, can be made of other materials.

Streptococcus agalactiae is a gram-positive bacterium that can cause various infectious diseases. Previously. the pathogen was mainly known to cause severe neonatal infections (e.g., neonatal sepsis), but now S. agalactiae has also been linked to food, specifically the consumption of raw fish. In 2015, there was a large outbreak of severe invasive infections in Singapore, predominantly septic arthritis and meningitis, which could be traced back to sequence type (ST)283 of S. agalactiae. Epidemiological investigations revealed that the consumption of raw freshwater fish (tilapia) was the trigger. Follow-up investigations used whole genome sequencing (WGS) to assess the prevalence of the bacterium more precisely. The result: S. agalactiae ST283 seems to have caused diseases in humans and farmed fish in Southeast Asia for decades. However, much remains unclear. If ST283 is transmitted exclusively from fish to humans, as was the case in the Singapore outbreak, then cases of S. agalactiae sepsis in Thailand and Laos are predominantly a food-borne disease. However, whether the transmission is from aquaculture to humans or vice versa, and whether there is an as yet unidentified reservoir, remains unknown. The germ could also be detected in tilapia from Brazil. Until now, the serotypes ST260 and ST927 were known in Brazil, but now ST283 also seems to be widespread. Based on import data of live tilapia from Singapore in 2014, a study suspects that the genotype was introduced into the country by the imported fish.

titel: Fish oil as a food supplement
kurzinfo: Currently, fish oil supplements are indicated for patients with elevated plasma triglycerides to reduce cardiovascular risk. Due to the high prevalence of elevated triglycerides in the population, they can be prescribed frequently. It is worth noting that low-dose omega-3 fatty acids are available over the counter. Some clinical studies suggest that omega-3 fatty acids may be associated with an increased risk of atrial fibrillation, the most common cardiac arrhythmia. People with this disorder are five times more likely to have a stroke. Lombardi et al (2021) found that omega-3 fatty acid supplementation was associated with a significantly increased risk of atrial fibrillation compared to placebo, with an incidence rate of 1.37 (95% confidence interval 1.22-1.54; p<0.001).

Upcycling is about the valorisation of waste from the food industry. Some initiatives focus on using by-products to produce new foods or functional ingredients. Others are about transforming food waste into entirely new raw materials. Examples that have made headlines range from high-fibre orange by-product flour to plastic-free food packaging based on a natural polymer derived from lobster shells. It's about being more sustainable, reducing 'food waste' and 'food loss'.

titel: Does palm oil promote the spread of cancer?
kurzinfo: Palm oil is obtained from the pulp of the palm fruit. The fruits are sterilised and pressed, resulting in the crude palm oil, CPO (Crude Palm Oil). Due to their high carotene content, fruits and oil have an orange-yellow to brown-red colour, which is removed during refining. Pure and fresh palm oil has a specific violet smell, a sweetish, pleasant taste and is clear and light in colour. Commercial oil, however, is usually cloudy and coloured due to less carefully executed preparation methods. The oil also becomes increasingly cloudy and has a more intense odour as it ages (Wikipedia). Fatty acid found in palm oil has been linked to the spread of cancer. Given that palm oil is in frequently used in our foods, this is a worrying report. The palmitic acid found in palm oil alters the genes of cancer cells and increases the likelihood of metastases forming.
The EPFL (école polytechnique fédérale de Lausanne) Food & You project will analyse the eating habits of 1000 people in order to develop personalised nutrition programmes.

The Research Institute of Organic Agriculture (FiBL) carried out an expert opinion on anthraquinone in food on behalf of bio Suisse. The study was published in February 2017. The reason for this was the finding that residues were detected in various organic and conventional products in recent years. Anthraquinone acts as a repellent against birds and was therefore previously used to dress seeds. It is therefore considered a pesticide. In the EU, however, its use has been forbidden for several years now because of health concerns. An analysis by the BNN (Bundesverband Naturkost Naturwaren), the Association of Organic Processors, Wholesalers and Retailers, of several thousand datasets showed that smoked products in particular have a significant increase in anthraquinone content and that there are no differences between organic and conventional products. The authors assume that drying or roasting processes promote the occurrence of anthraquinones. It is further assumed that drying and possibly smoking processes are the main contributors to anthraquinone residues. The EFSA concludes in its expert opinion on anthraquinone as an active substance in plant protection products that carcinogenic effects related to anthraquinone cannot be ruled out and that the risk potential in mammals cannot be explicitly determined. The International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) classifies the substance as a possible carcinogen for humans ("Group 2B").

A recent study identified a novel human circovirus in an immunocompromised 66-year-old woman with sudden onset of self-limiting hepatitis in Switzerland. The authors detected human circovirus 1 (HCirV-1) transcripts in hepatocytes and the HCirV-1 genome long-term in the patient’s blood, stool, and urine. The patient lives alone in rural Switzerland, without direct contact with animals. She had not traveled outside Switzerland during the past 8 years. Her dietary habits were unremarkable except for sporadic consumption of raw calf liver, which she most recently consumed before 2018. She eats cured pork and beef products and gets milk from the supermarket. Circoviruses are an emerging group of DNA viruses with largely unknown pathogenicity in humans.

There are reports in the media about a new, possibly infection-causing structure, called BMMF (ring-shaped genetic elements, similar to the plasmids of bacteria). However, the nature of the postulated pathogens, which lie between viruses and bacteria, does not seem to be clear yet. The German Cancer Research Centre (DKFZ) reports: the distribution pattern of new colorectal and breast cancer cases observed worldwide suggests a close connection between the consumption of milk and meat products from European cattle (Bos taurus).The hypothesis is: an infection with a previously unknown pathogen transmitted by consuming dairy products and/or beef occurs in early infancy. The pathogens induce a chronic inflammatory reaction in certain tissues (intestine, breast), which can promote the development of cancer in the surrounding tissue. The outbreak of the disease occurs decades after the infection! Possible causative agents could be the BMMFs, single-stranded ring-shaped DNA elements that show great similarity to sequences of specific bacterial plasmids. Most BMMFs show similarity to plasmids of Acinetobacter baumannii. Some BMMFs also show similarities to certain viruses with small, circular, single-stranded DNA genomes. The nature of these pathogens has not yet been clearly defined. They represent a new class of pathogens that are, in their characteristics, between viruses and bacteria. Therefore, in view of the relationship to plasmids, the name "plasmidomes" was chosen for this previously unknown class of pathogens.
